results.abstract: Atlas and Titan 2 rockets from 1960's space program are hauled through Manhattan and Brooklyn to New York Hall of Science in Queens; have undergone $2 million overhaul; photo (M)

headline.main: The Final Frontier: Queens; Museum's Rockets Return After a Tuneup in Ohio

results.snippet: You can see a lot of strange things on a New York City street, but on Wednesday night there was something almost literally out of this world.    Two extra-long flatbed trucks rumbled into Manhattan looking as if they had made a wrong turn at Cape...
results.lead_paragraph: You can see a lot of strange things on a New York City street, but on Wednesday night there was something almost literally out of this world. Two extra-long flatbed trucks rumbled into Manhattan looking as if they had made a wrong turn at Cape Canaveral. Each truck carried a vintage rocket built four decades ago to soar into space, a voyage that some days seems less difficult than a trip across Midtown.

results.abstract: Benamin Genocchio reviews JFK and Art, exhibit at Bruce Museum of Arts and Sciences in Greenwich, Conn, coinciding with 40th anniversary of Kennedy's assassination; photos (M)

headline.main: Artistic Image Makers Of a Presidency

results.snippet: JOHN F. KENNEDY fascinated and inspired artists in a way no other American president has done. Partly, this was because of his youthful good looks, beautiful family and extraordinary charisma, and partly because he carried with him so many hopes for...
results.lead_paragraph: JOHN F. KENNEDY fascinated and inspired artists in a way no other American president has done. Partly, this was because of his youthful good looks, beautiful family and extraordinary charisma, and partly because he carried with him so many hopes for a brighter, better future. To many Americans, including artists, he seemed like the model president. Coinciding with the 40th anniversary of Kennedy's assassination on Nov. 22, 1963, the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich is presenting ''J.F.K. and Art,'' an exhibition of artistic responses to the man, his myth and legacy. It is the first exhibition in the United States to explore this theme, and is accompanied by a catalog with some new scholarship.

results.abstract: China announces that Shezhou V (Divine Vessel), its first piloted space flight, will lift off sometime next week; Shenzou will be launched from Gobi desert and circle earth 14 times; it is unclear how many crew members will be aboard; news release clears up conflicting reports in Chinese press about launching (M)

headline.main: China Says Its First Space Flight Will Be Launched Next Week

results.snippet: The government finally cleared up the mystery of China's first piloted space flight, announcing Friday, via the official New China News Agency, that Shezhou V, or Divine Vessel, would lift off late next week, and -- according to an unidentified space...
results.lead_paragraph: The government finally cleared up the mystery of China's first piloted space flight, announcing Friday, via the official New China News Agency, that Shezhou V, or Divine Vessel, would lift off late next week, and -- according to an unidentified space official -- circle the earth 14 times. It is still not clear how many Chinese crew members, known here as taikonauts, will be on board. But the Shenzhou will blast off from a site in the Gobi Desert at what the agency called ''an appropriate time'' -- and definitely between next Wednesday and Friday, after next week's much awaited Third Plenum of the ruling Communist party's Central Committee.

results.abstract: Benjamin Genocchio reviews exhibit JFK and Art at Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn; photo (M)

headline.main: In the Eyes of Artists: Responses to Kennedy

results.snippet: JOHN F. KENNEDY fascinated and inspired artists in a way no other American president has done. Partly this was because of his youthful good looks, beautiful family and extraordinary charisma, and partly because he carried with him so many hopes for a...
results.lead_paragraph: JOHN F. KENNEDY fascinated and inspired artists in a way no other American president has done. Partly this was because of his youthful good looks, beautiful family and extraordinary charisma, and partly because he carried with him so many hopes for a brighter, better future. To many Americans, including artists, he seemed like the model president. Coinciding with the 40th anniversary of Kennedy's assassination on Nov. 22, 1963, the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich is presenting ''J.F.K. and Art,'' an exhibition of artistic responses to the man, his myth and legacy. It is the first exhibition in the United States to explore this theme, and is accompanied by a catalog with some new scholarship.

results.snippet: Best Bet      At 15, Randolph Herr said, he realized that ''I absolutely had no ability to play the piano.'' But he believed the sound of a live piano was superior to recorded music.    ''It's like comparing fresh food to TV dinners,'' he said.
results.lead_paragraph: Best Bet At 15, Randolph Herr said, he realized that ''I absolutely had no ability to play the piano.'' But he believed the sound of a live piano was superior to recorded music. ''It's like comparing fresh food to TV dinners,'' he said.

results.abstract: China hopes to become third nation to send astronaut into space; with launch planned for Oct 15, Chinese leaders hope to send new message to two audiences; to rest of world, China is displaying its growing technological prowess, staking its claim to future role in space and reasserting its case for being considered power equal to United States; to its own people, Chinese leadership hopes to stir pride and nationalism and to prove that Communist Party is capable of most technical of achievements; photo (M)

headline.main: China Plans Giant Step This Week

results.snippet: Amid all the clutter that has been rocketed into space is a clunky satellite expected to circle the Earth until 2070. The satellite, the Dong Fang Hong, was the first ever launched by China, in 1970, and is also an extraterrestrial boombox: It...
results.lead_paragraph: Amid all the clutter that has been rocketed into space is a clunky satellite expected to circle the Earth until 2070. The satellite, the Dong Fang Hong, was the first ever launched by China, in 1970, and is also an extraterrestrial boombox: It broadcasts into the cosmos the strains of the Maoist anthem, ''The East is Red.'' If China becomes the third nation to send an astronaut into space, as it plans to do on Wednesday, its top leaders will be sending a new message, to two audiences.

results.abstract: Astronauts American Dr C Michael Foale and Russian Aleksandr Y Kaleri are scheduled to arrive at International Space Station to continue scientific research as well as maintain facility; Foale is astrophysicist with five previous flights and 178 total days in space; Kaleri is senior astronaut with Energiya Space Corporation and has 416 days in space, primarily aboard Mir, Russian space station; Spanish astronaut Pedro Duque is scheduled to spend eight days aboard station and return with current crew (M)

headline.main: Meanwhile, Up at the Space Station . . .

results.snippet: The astronauts who will soon depart for six months aboard the International Space Station say they have real work to do, including a full load of scientific research, and will be more than a caretaker crew.    The next pair of space station...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts who will soon depart for six months aboard the International Space Station say they have real work to do, including a full load of scientific research, and will be more than a caretaker crew. The next pair of space station residents, an American and a Russian, is scheduled to blast off on Saturday to relieve a crew of two that has been aboard since April. The new crew, accompanied by a Spanish astronaut for the trip up, is to journey to the station aboard a Russian Soyuz spacecraft launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

results.abstract: China prepares to become third nation to launch person into space, but extreme secrecy that surrounded American-Russian space race seems to have given way to somewhat open program that recognizes economic advantage of selling space technology; fast economic growth in China coupled with purchases from established Russian program have provided base for Shenzhou spacecraft; Chinese rocket history, including struggle to increase reliability, discussed; future global space race hypothesized; photos; drawings (L)
results.snippet: When Moscow put the first humans into space 42 years ago, Soviet officials raised a veil of secrecy. They made sure the genius behind the feat was a nonperson, awarding his medals in private. They lied about the spaceport's location. And they said...
results.lead_paragraph: When Moscow put the first humans into space 42 years ago, Soviet officials raised a veil of secrecy. They made sure the genius behind the feat was a nonperson, awarding his medals in private. They lied about the spaceport's location. And they said the heroic astronaut had landed his spacecraft, when in fact he had ejected from his capsule high in the atmosphere and parachuted back to earth. Now, as China prepares to become the third nation to fire a person into space, perhaps as soon as Wednesday morning Beijing time, the differences are telling.

results.abstract: Chinese spacecraft Shenzhou 5 blasts off from Gobi Desert carrying astronaut Lt Col Yang Liewi on mission of about 21 hours that makes China third nation to send man into space; photos (M)

headline.main: China Sends a Man Into Orbit, Entering the U.S.-Russian Club

results.snippet: The Chinese spacecraft Shenzhou 5 blasted off from the Gobi Desert on Wednesday carrying a single astronaut. The launching left government leaders jubilant yet also anxiously awaiting his safe return so China can stake its claim as one of the world's...
results.lead_paragraph: The Chinese spacecraft Shenzhou 5 blasted off from the Gobi Desert on Wednesday carrying a single astronaut. The launching left government leaders jubilant yet also anxiously awaiting his safe return so China can stake its claim as one of the world's elite space-faring nations. The launching took place about 9 a.m., according to the state-run television network, CCTV. At about 9:30, the network showed a videotape of the rocket soaring to the heavens.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-10    U.S. Resolution on Iraq Gaining Support in the U.N.  The Bush administration is virtually assured of gaining Security Council approval of a revised United Nations resolution on Iraq's future, diplomats said, but it remains...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 U.S. Resolution on Iraq Gaining Support in the U.N. The Bush administration is virtually assured of gaining Security Council approval of a revised United Nations resolution on Iraq's future, diplomats said, but it remains unclear whether the measure will be adopted overwhelmingly or in a less convincing, abstention-riddled vote. A1 A car bomb exploded outside the Turkish Embassy in Baghdad, killing the bomber and one bystander, and wounding several people. The attack follows the announcement of a plan by the Turkish government to contribute 10,000 troops to the occupation. A10

results.abstract: Shenzhou 5 spacecraft makes safe landing on grasslands of Inner Mongolia, completing apparently successful mission that establishes China as only third nation to send person into space; launching and landing are not televised live, but within minutes grainy images of search teams inspecting Shenzhou 5 re-entry capsule are televised to nation, as is successful emergence from space capsule of astronaut Yang Liwei; Yang takes short, congratulatory telephone call from Chinese Prime Min Wen Jiabao; photos (M)

headline.main: After 21 Hours, Chinese Spacecraft Lands Safely

results.snippet: With parachutes braking its swift fall to Earth, the Shenzhou 5 spacecraft made a safe, early morning landing on the grasslands of Inner Mongolia on Thursday, official news organizations reported, completing an apparently successful mission that...
results.lead_paragraph: With parachutes braking its swift fall to Earth, the Shenzhou 5 spacecraft made a safe, early morning landing on the grasslands of Inner Mongolia on Thursday, official news organizations reported, completing an apparently successful mission that established China as only the third nation to send a person into space. State television reported that the touchdown occurred at 6:23 a.m, about 21 hours after the spaceship blasted off on Wednesday from the Gobi Desert carrying the nation's first ''taikonaut,'' Yang Liwei, a lieutenant colonel in the Chinese military. Within minutes, grainy images of search teams inspecting the Shenzhou 5 re-entry capsule were televised to the nation. The launching and the landing were not televised live.

results.abstract: China pledges to return to space within one or two years, just hours after safe return of Shenzhou 5 and astrounaut Yang Liwei (M)

headline.main: Elated, China Promises Another Space Flight in a Year or Two

results.snippet: Within hours of the safe return of the Shenzhou 5 early Thursday, China pledged to return to space within one or two years, as officials outlined a short-term space agenda that included space walks, space docking and the possible construction of a...
results.lead_paragraph: Within hours of the safe return of the Shenzhou 5 early Thursday, China pledged to return to space within one or two years, as officials outlined a short-term space agenda that included space walks, space docking and the possible construction of a space lab or space station. The swift commitment underscored the confidence and enthusiasm infused into the space program by the Shenzhou 5 mission, which established China as the third nation to send an astronaut into space.

results.abstract: China's success in sending astronaut into orbit is reminder that any modern aspirant to world power down on Earth ultimately ends up in space; photo (S)

headline.main: Smiling Like Venus, Wary Like Mars

results.snippet: THERE is no space race or cold war, but China's success in sending an astronaut into orbit last week is a reminder that any modern aspirant to world power down on Earth ultimately ends up in space. The reasons are ego and potential plunder, but also...
results.lead_paragraph: THERE is no space race or cold war, but China's success in sending an astronaut into orbit last week is a reminder that any modern aspirant to world power down on Earth ultimately ends up in space. The reasons are ego and potential plunder, but also the fact that the world's most powerful nations fear that space could one day be a setting for war. If that sounds like science fiction, consider this passage: ''We know from history that every medium -- air, land and sea -- has seen conflict. Reality indicates that space will be no different.''

results.abstract: International crew blasts off from Kazakhstan and heads for International Space Station for 200-day mission (S)

headline.main: A New Crew Heads For the Space Station

results.snippet: An international crew blasted off and headed to the International Space Station on Saturday for a 200-day mission, days after China's first manned space flight led to speculation that it might join the space station project.    With the United...
results.lead_paragraph: An international crew blasted off and headed to the International Space Station on Saturday for a 200-day mission, days after China's first manned space flight led to speculation that it might join the space station project. With the United States' space shuttles still grounded after a disaster this year, the station's survival depends on Russian spacecraft. The Soyuz TMA-3 craft, with its three-man crew, is scheduled to dock with the orbital platform early on Monday.

results.abstract: Op-Ed article by Jacqueline Newmyer says United States has properly extended its congratulations to Chinese space program, but it should also be wary of China's intentions; says contrast between United States' open space program and China's clandestine approach is stark; says that amid calls for joint scientific or commercial ventures in space to improve Chinese-American relations, officials in Washington should consider what kind of cooperation is appropriate with regime that does not share American tradition of freedom and respect for human rights; diagram (M)

headline.main: Will the Space Race Move East?

results.snippet: Something that went up in the first Chinese manned spacecraft did not come down. The Shenzhou 5, which orbited Earth 14 times last week, left behind an orbital module carrying equipment capable of capturing images of the earth's surface. This...
results.lead_paragraph: Something that went up in the first Chinese manned spacecraft did not come down. The Shenzhou 5, which orbited Earth 14 times last week, left behind an orbital module carrying equipment capable of capturing images of the earth's surface. This satellite could be used for many purposes, including the monitoring of United States military forces. Of course, China, like the United States and Russia, has been launching similar reconnaissance satellites for decades. And Lt. Col. Yang Liwei and the Chinese space program deserve the accolades they have received for the successful voyage of the Shenzhou 5. But while the United States properly extends its congratulations -- and entertains talk of three-way cooperation with Russia and the newest member of the space club -- it should also be wary of China's intentions.

results.abstract: Russian capsule carrying American, Russian and Spanish astronauts docks at International Space Station (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Russian Capsule Docks With Space Station

results.snippet: A capsule with a three-member crew docked with the International Space Station carrying letters for the two astronauts there. The crew, who blasted off in their Soyuz vessel on Saturday from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, performed three...
results.lead_paragraph: A capsule with a three-member crew docked with the International Space Station carrying letters for the two astronauts there. The crew, who blasted off in their Soyuz vessel on Saturday from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, performed three hours of checks before crawling through a hatch and floating, weightless, into the station. The American mission commander, Dr. C. Michael Foale, and the Russian astronaut, Alejsander Y. Kaleri, will spend 200 days on the $95 billion orbital platform. A Spaniard, Pedro Duque, will carry out a week of experiments before returning home.

results.abstract: NASA officials acknowledge that air, water and radiation monitors, medical devices and some other systems on International Space Station are ailing or broken; astronauts aboard station and some NASA officials hold news conference, saying they are confident that station is safe for now; say situation is being carefully monitored and astronauts could be evacuated quickly if problems worsen; fresh crew, one American and one Russian, arrived aboard spacecraft on Oct 20 for six-month stay, along with Spanish astronaut who will return to Earth in 10 days with departing crew of two; photo (M)

headline.main: Problems on Space Station Stir Debate About Safety

results.snippet: NASA officials acknowledged yesterday that air, water and radiation monitors, medical devices and some other systems on the International Space Station were ailing or broken.    But in news conferences, the astronauts aboard the station and a number...

byline.original: By ANDREW C. REVKIN and WARREN E. LEARY; John Schwartz contributed reporting for this article

results.lead_paragraph: NASA officials acknowledged yesterday that air, water and radiation monitors, medical devices and some other systems on the International Space Station were ailing or broken. But in news conferences, the astronauts aboard the station and a number of space agency officials said they were confident that the station was safe for now. They said that the situation was being carefully monitored and that the astronauts could be evacuated quickly if problems worsened.

results.abstract: Russian Mission Control reports that Soyuz space capsule carrying American, Russian and Spaniard landed safely in wide-open steppes of Kazakhstan; 3.5-hour descent to Earth is only second time American astronaut has come home in Russian craft and landed on foreign soil; Russian Soyuz capsules have been linchpin of Iternational Space Station program since NASA manned space flights were put on hold following Columbia disaster (M)

headline.main: 3 Return to Earth in Russian Space Capsule

results.snippet: A Soyuz space capsule carrying an American, a Russian and a Spaniard landed safely on Tuesday in the wide-open steppes of Kazakhstan, Russian Mission Control said.    The 3.5-hour descent to Earth was only the second time that an American astronaut...
results.lead_paragraph: A Soyuz space capsule carrying an American, a Russian and a Spaniard landed safely on Tuesday in the wide-open steppes of Kazakhstan, Russian Mission Control said. The 3.5-hour descent to Earth was only the second time that an American astronaut had come home in a Russian craft and landed on foreign soil. Since the disintegration of the space shuttle Columbia in February put NASA manned space flights on hold, the Russian Soyuz capsules have been the linchpin of the International Space Station program.

results.abstract: House committee leaders Reps Sherwood Boehlert and Ralph M Hall ask NASA to postpone plans for Orbital Space Plane program because of uncertainties about its role and costs, letter to Admr Sean O'Keefe; holds it is mistake to proceed until national consensus develops about future of human spaceflight; NASA wants plane to serve as lifeboat for astronauts aboard International Space Station and as vehicle to transfer crews to and from space station; craft, in early design stages, would not replace larger, cargo-carrying space shuttle (M)

headline.main: Not So Fast, Lawmakers Say Of NASA Plans For Space Plane

results.snippet: The leaders of the House Science Committee have asked NASA to postpone plans for a new astronaut-carrying space vehicle because of uncertainties about its role and costs.    In a letter to the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, released on Monday, the...
results.lead_paragraph: The leaders of the House Science Committee have asked NASA to postpone plans for a new astronaut-carrying space vehicle because of uncertainties about its role and costs. In a letter to the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, released on Monday, the lawmakers said it was a mistake to proceed with the Orbital Space Plane program before the country developed a consensus about the future of human spaceflight.
